content: The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen. The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include fishing businesses in the definition of elected farm income. The term 'fishing business' is defined as the conduct of commercial fishing. The term 'fishing business' is defined as the conduct of commercial fishing under the Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF FISHING SAFETY EQUIPMENT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for a fishing safety equipment credit. The fishing safety equipment credit allows eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business to claim a credit of 75% of qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, up to a maximum of $1,500 per year. Eligible expenses include those paid for safety equipment used in connection with the fishing business. The term 'qualified fishing safety equipment expenses' refers to expenses for lifesaving equipment required for a fishing business. Special rules apply, including aggregation rules for related entities. No double benefit deduction is allowed. The text discusses the treatment of employers under specific sections for tax purposes, denial of double benefits for deductions, and basis adjustment for equipment credits. Additionally, it limits the carryback of fishing safety equipment credits before a certain effective date. The text limits the carryback of fishing safety equipment credits before a specific effective date and includes conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The text amends the Internal Revenue Code to limit the carryback of fishing safety equipment credits and includes conforming amendments. The amendments made by this Act regarding fishing safety equipment credits will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
